   LP
 CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS 

 . Dina Dublon, CFO   . David (Phonetic), (Indiscernible)   . Mark (Phonetic), (Indiscernible) 

   TD
 OVERVIEW 

 Retail led the way again with another record quarter. Weak trading offset the gains and drove results lower. The commercial portfolio remains under pressure, led by telecom and cable. Q&A Focus: On general surety bonds. 

 FINANCIAL DATA 

 A. Key Data From Call   1. Operating EPS = $0.58.   2. Operating earnings = $1.2b.   3. Return on equity = 11%. 

 PRESENTATION SUMMARY 

 A. 2Q02 RESULTS   1. 2Q02 earnings were comparable to 1Q02, but below analyst      consensus estimate.   2. JPM gained market share in investment bank, in a market that      continues to shrink.   3. Weak trading more than offset the gains and drove results lower.   4. Tech and telecom continues to drive the write-downs.   5. Operating EPS was $0.58 a share, up $0.01 from 1Q02 and up over      50% from 2001, because of the very large write-downs in JP      Morgan Partners in 2001.   6. Excluding JP Morgan Partners, EPS is slightly down 3-4% from both 2001 and 1Q02.   7. Reported EPS, net of the previously announced merger and      relocation charges was $0.50.   8. These charges were $230m pre tax.   9. For 2H02 non-operating merger charges were estimated at about      $700m.   10. Revenues were up 9% from 2Q01.   11. Excluding JP Morgan Partners, revenues were flat, but with a      significant change in mix.   12. Over $700m increases in revenues from retail offset the $600m      revenue decline in investment bank. 13. Total revenues were flat to 1Q with a very similar change in mix, lower trading revenues, and higher retail revenues.   14. JPM continues to manage a positive operating leverage by      reducing expenses.   15. Credit costs are up significantly from 2001.   16. 2Q02 operating earnings were $1.2b.   17. ROE was 11% for 2Q02 and for 1H02. 18. Expenses are down 3% from 1Q02 and 5% from 2Q01.   19. OPEX include $160m in non-merger, severance, and related costs.   20. OPEX was up from about $100m in 1Q02.   21. Costs will continue to flow through the operating line.   22. Credit costs are high, but stable. 23. Commercial charge-offs were $290m or almost 1.2% of commercial loans.   24. Managed credit card charge-offs are higher.   25. Providian charge-offs are up from 1Q02.   26. Total provision (Phonetic) equaled charge-off in 2Q02 and 1Q02.   27. JPM holds reserves against retained consumer loans.   28. Providian and other card securitizations and lower loss rate in      auto finance contributed to $130m relief in consumer reserves.   29. JPM increased the unallocated portion of the total reserve by      $120m.   30. Unallocated reserves are now over $800m, 16% of total reserves      vs. 14% in 1Q, and 11% in 2Q01.   31. JPM's policy is to stay between 10% and 20%.   32. Non-performing assets are up slightly to $4.4b from additions      primarily in the telecom sector.   33. Argentine credit exposure net of reserves is about $200m. 34. JPM managed its Brazilian exposure down to $2.1b as of the end of 2Q02, from $3.3b at the end of the year.   35. Reserves of $5b are unchanged from 1Q02 and up $1.3b from 2001.   36. Loans were down and are leading to an increase in the      reserve-to-loan ratio of about 70 basis points.   37. The commercial portfolio remains under pressure, led by telecom      and cable.   38. JPM expects total reserves to stay at about the same level.   39. Retail and middle market posted record earnings of $686m, up      29% from 1Q02 and 60% from 2001.   40. ROE was 26% and for the 1H, it was 24%.   41. Retail was almost 60% of consolidated earnings of 2Q02.   42. Revenues of $3.5b were driven by consumer-lending businesses.   43. Compared to 2001, Providian adds 10% to revenue growth and 5%      to expense growth.   44. Overhead ratio declined to 48%.   45. Continued to show organic growth in cards for the seventh      consecutive quarter adding 900,000 in new accounts.   46. Deposits are up 12% from 2001.   47. Home finance income almost doubled from 2001.   48. JPM had net hedging gain of $160m.   49. Even if the environment continues to be positive as expected by      JPM, revenues and earnings for retail may be lower for the rest      of 2001.   50. Treasury and security services also had a record quarter, with earnings up 22% from 1Q02 and 16% from 2001.   51. ROE rebounded to 23%.   52. Revenues at $985m are up 2% from 2001 and up 5% from 1Q02. 53. Revenues are up 9% from pickup in custody fees, foreign exchange revenues, and securities lending fee.   54. Institutional revenues are up 9%.   55. Treasury services revenues are down 1% vs. both 1Q02 and 2Q02.   56. Deposit levels and fees are up in the business.   57. Expenses are under control.   58. Overhead ratio dropped to 72%.   59. The group works towards a long-term overhead ratio of 68%.   60. Earnings in the investment bank are at $485m, down 35% and 38%      from prior periods on very weak revenue and high credit costs. 61. JPM put in place a new client coverage model and included in operating expenses, severance related charges of $120m, up from $50m in 1Q.   62. Overhead ratio for 2Q02 was 65% and it's 62% YTD. 63. Excluding the severance-related cost, the ratio is 61% for 2Q02 and 59% YTD.   64. ROE for 2Q02 was 10% and 13% YTD. 

 B. INVESTMENT BANK REVENUE   1. Trading and brokerage commissions combined are at $1.4b are down      over 20% from 2001 and 1Q02.   2. Weak trading, particularly in June, drove the decline.   3. Fixed income is down 11% from 2001 because of declines in      emerging market trading.   4. Equities are down 45% from the 2Q01, primarily equity derivatives.   5. The decline from the 1Q02 is primarily from cash business.   6. Trading was unusually weak in June and may rebound.   7. The outlook for the 2H remains very uncertain. 

 C. MARKET SHARE PROGRESS   1. JPM maintained or increased strength of market share relative to      2001.   2. In each case, market share in 2Q was higher than in the 1H02,      highlighting the momentum in 2Q. 3. Market gain shares really validate the value to clients of the broad investment-banking model.   4. Seeing the benefits from the investment in equities.   5. JPM is outpacing in a shrinking market. 6. YTD global disclosed fees for the market are down about 15% vs. 2Q01, up 30%.   7. Equity markets activity is running at 98 levels.   8. M&A is running at 95 levels.   9. Syndicated loan volumes increased very modestly from 1Q02, but      are down compared to 2001. 

 D. INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT AND PRIVATE BANKING   1. Earnings are about the same as of 2Q01, as expense reductions      more than offset lower revenues and higher credit costs.   2. Earnings are down 6% from 1Q02. 3. Return on equity was 8%.   4. Tangible return on equity is in excess of 20%.   5. The pre tax margin was 21%, up from 2Q01, but down 22% from      1Q02.   6. Private bank revenues, about half of the total revenues of the      group, declined 9% from 1Q02 on lower client activity.   7. Investment management revenues were flat with 1Q.   8. Assets under management fell $40b from the end of March to      $540b. 9. Retail assets under management are up 11% from 2001 and flat with March, despite market depreciation.   10. JP Morgan Partners had a private equity loss that narrowed to a      $125m.   11. 70% of the write-downs and write-offs came from tech and      telecom and remain at high levels.   12. Realized gains of $110m that partially offset the write-downs      and write-offs.   13. The mark-to-market on the public portfolio had less of an      impact in 2Q.   14. Losses were partially offset by hedge gains and the gain on the      Jet Blue IPO.   15. The public portfolio now in the books is at about $700m.   16. JPM have a few transactions in the pipeline and is expected to      close in 3Q. 17. Seagate Technologies has filed for an IPO, which is scheduled for the 2H02. 

 E. BALANCE SHEET   1. JPM's Tier 1 capital ratio remains high at 8.7%, up from 8.3% at      year-end.   2. JPM is not repurchasing stock.   3. Assets are up 4% from 1Q02 due to increase in trading assets.   4. Commercial loans are down 77% (Phonetic)from 2001 and are      slightly up this quarter.   5. Risk-weighted assets are down from 1Q as well as from year-end. 

 F. SUMMARY   1. Diversification has helped to maintain operating results.   2. Earnings from the investment bank are down $300m from 2001, a      38% decline.   3. The increase in retail and services is over $280m, making up for      most of the decline.   4. Continued to strengthen the franchise in both retail or      investment banking.   5. Capital market businesses continued to suffer from slow      corporate activity and reduced market values with no clear      turning point yet.   6. Regarding short-term, JPM sees no improvement with potentially      some pressure in revenues and credit.   7. JPM recognizes that reputation is one of its most valuable      assets. 

 G. PLUSES AND MINUSES   1. POSITIVES     1. JPM had a great performance in the retail side, with record        revenues and record earnings.     2. Investment banking market share picked up across the board,        across all products.     3. Credit costs are stable in a difficult environment.   2. NEGATIVES     1. Credit costs are still high relative to historical standards.     2. Investment banking revenues, particularly trading revenues,        are weak relative to historical standards and the potential of        the company.     3. Private equity continues to show losses and not much        opportunity for realized gain. 

 H. CLOSING REMARKS   1. JPM's goal is simply to continue with the strategy it has and to      continue to execute on the strategy until it gets to that time      when the bottom-line results can show the benefit of that.   2. Continues to believe that they have a tremendous operating      leverage. 

 QUESTION AND ANSWER SUMMARY 

 Q1.  The EPS run rate for the last two years has been around $2 and that  even at the NASDAQ peak in 1999, you never got to that level. At what point is it appropriate to address the current dividend level  and consider cutting it until some of these cyclical problems  resolve? 

 A.  Our outlook depends on the visibility for getting to the $4-4.5, which would be comfortable with our policy. It takes three things to get there. It takes a more normal private equity revenue rate, a  more normal trading and investment-banking environment, and credit  costs at normal levels. If those three things happen, then we would  be at that earnings level. We feel comfortable waiting as long as  we're comfortably covering the dividend and as long as we are  increasing our capital ratios. We believe that we will get to those  levels. If those conditions change, then I think we would reassess  that, but at the present time, that continues to be how we feel  about it. 

 A.  I guess what I took away from what you were saying is that the earnings in the retail business were boosted by the hedge gains, so retail earnings will probably be down in the 2H, and you don't see anything turning around in investment banking in the 2H, to see earnings improving in the 2H from what they were in the 1H and possibly could be weaker. 

 Q2.  Trading results were weak as you pointed out and they seemed to be  weaker than some of your peers who were on the same calendar quarter. Could you elaborate on that a little bit? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  Our results on a prior-year quarter, on a quarterly basis, do look weak, but we had a very strong quarter a year ago. It was about  $1.6b in revenues. We had a very strong quarter in 1Q02. It was  about $1.7b. This quarter came in at $1.1b, $200m of that difference  was emerging markets, largely Brazil. Another third of it was  related to the rates business and weakness in the rates business in  the prior periods. The final part was the equities derivatives  business. So, the equity derivatives were strong in the 2Q01. That's  largely related to deal flow, lack of deal activity in that market,  and that's where we've seen the weaknesses. We're looking at these  from a reasonably strong level. `DUE TO DIFFICULTIES IN CALL AUDIO,  THIS PORTION OF THE EVENT BRIEF Q&A HAS BEEN EXCLUDED. ` We were at  $1.7b in the 1Q01, $1.1b was a low quarter for us overall and $200m  of that related to our emerging markets in Brazil. I think it's the  ups and downs of the trading business. But I think we came from a  very high 1Q. 

 A.  We were at $1.7b in the 1Q01, $1.1b was a low quarter for us overall, but if you take $200m of that related to our emerging  markets in Brazil, I think it's the ups and downs of the trading  business. But I think we came from a very high 1Q. 

 Q3.  Can you comment more on the outlook for the 2H02? 

 A.  I don't have much to add on what I said before. We can all look at the numbers. There isn't much visibility on the investment banking side. What we have is somewhat based (Phonetic) on trading results because June was particularly weak. On the other hand, we had some unusual items hedging as well. In this quarter, we had unusually low trading and somewhat unusual market-sensitive items on the mortgage banking side. For the remainder of the year, it's more of the same (Indiscernible) as being management. 

 Q4.  Given the revenue weakness, where do you stand on expense initiatives? How much expense savings do you have and what is left?  On venture capital, how scrubbed is the private portion of the  portfolio and what kind of losses are you looking at? Could you just  comment on some of the regulatory investigations? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  With regard to expense initiatives, I think we continue to be very focused on expenses. We have continued to reduce people, especially  in those areas where we have revenue declines, which are primarily  in investment management and treasury securities services and in investment banking. In the consumer business, where we have strong volume growth, we are adding people to deal with the volume growth  and expense growth that is lower than our revenue growth, even when  you make all the various adjustments. So I think it is something  that we are clearly cognizant of, the need to keep the pressure on  expenses, and we continue to do so. Because we push all of the costs  of doing that into our operating expenses, it doesn't show up quite  as immediately as it did if you were pushing it to a non-operating  cost. But I think it is clear that we're going to continue to focus  on those initiatives. Six Sigma has been a very important part of  what we are doing. It was utilized first in the retail bank because  they weren't going through a merger and I think they have several  $100m of payback from it. We're applying it more broadly across the  company now as we have gotten through with the merger and I think we  will see additional fruits from that. On the venture capital, we  feel comfortable with our evaluations. We have a very intensive  process that we go through of looking at each company that is  subject to both people in the company and people outside of the  private equities side taking an independent look at it. The market,  especially in telecommunications, has continued to decline. I think  with that, there have been some write-downs in our portfolio. I  can't predict whether that market is going to continue to decline.  At some point, I know it won't. But as long as it is, there probably  will be some continued write-downs. There's some sign that it may be  getting close to the bottom, but we'll have to see whether that works out or not. With regard to investigations, I think everybody  is investigating everything that is associated with some of the  highly visible transactions. We are comfortable that what we did was  the right thing and understand why they want to investigate, and we  are cooperative with them. `DUE TO DIFFICULTIES IN CALL AUDIO, THIS  PORTION OF THE EVENT TRANSCRIPT HAS BEEN EXCLUDED. ` 

 Q5.  `DUE TO DIFFICULTIES IN CALL AUDIO, THIS PORTION OF THE EVENT TRANSCRIPT HAS BEEN EXCLUDED. ` 

 A.  `DUE TO DIFFICULTIES IN CALL AUDIO, THIS PORTION OF THE EVENT TRANSCRIPT HAS BEEN EXCLUDED. ` Scores of that portfolio are not significantly different than our own, but they had not worked the portfolio in the same way that we do in terms of talking to people  and being an active management of balances, as people become  delinquent or not. So, we felt that the charge-offs would be higher  and the model that we used in the acquisition are called forth to be  higher than it has turned out to be. So, when we say our charge-off  ratio is higher because of the inclusion of it for a full quarter as  opposed to two months, it is not that we are disappointed in the  results. That's what we expected to happen. We're actually making  more money on a bottom-line basis than we expected to make in the  first six months of the acquisition. We think over time it will turn  out to be a terrific moneymaking proposition, though it even is  today. So it simply means that our ratio is higher than it would  have otherwise been, but we're not disappointed in it. 

 Q6.  On the private equity, you were saying the issue was really not on  the write-downs but more on the realized gain side. Was that what you were inferring? (Henry McVey - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter) 

 A.  I was inferring that we are not expecting any large write-downs on JP Morgan Partners. We don't have the same concentration issues that we had a year ago. In order for us to see a positive bottom line, we need to see (Indiscernible). That's not to say we won't have write-downs. 

 A.  I you look at historical levels of write-downs, they would have run  for some long period of time in the range of a $100-150m a quarter and even $200m a quarter would not be unusual. It is not so unusual  to have $200m in write-downs. What's unusual is that we don't have  the realized gains to offset that. You would expect in the portfolio  of our size to be in the neighborhood of $500m a quarter. 

 Q7.  The home finance went from 132 to 268 and auto finance went from 33  to 82. I heard you mention that there was a gain on a hedge. Was there anything else that really bolstered those numbers? (Henry  McVey - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter) 

 A.  Yes. In auto finance, we had a reduction in the credit loss allowance, in the provision, because our methodology is predicated  on delinquencies, current losses, retained loans, and expectations  of future losses, and also average holding period. So, for this  quarter, the reserve in that business was higher than it needed to  be. In addition to the fact it had very good volume growth and very  much wider spreads in that business. As people have gotten out of  that business and as there's less competition in that business. And  as we're in a favorable interest rate environment, we have seen  spreads widen in that business. With regard to the mortgage  business, it was partially helped by hedge gains. But also it would  be true to say that origination gains, the warehouse effect, spreads  on warehouse's loans, and the positive continued increase in  servicing also contributed to the improved earnings. 

 Q8.  You said in your commentary that you expect continued revenue pressure and continued high credit costs. If you infer that you are saying that the consumer bucket is getting better. So, most of the issues that we should be looking for on the credit side are related  to the corporate? (Henry McVey - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter) 

 A.  Consistent with what we said in the 1Q that consumer costs are getting better. Consumer credit is getting better. We are still  seeing continued positive delinquency. That will probably mean that  provisions in the consumer area will probably continue to be  somewhat less that actual charge-offs. On the commercial side, it's  possibly the reverse, although we're seeing a leveling out of  problems and although there's a lot of stuff in the news, it's not  necessarily new news to us. We're charging off a significant amount  of loans as we try to stay ahead of this game. For the provision to  go up, your loans have to deteriorate by more than what you charge  off. And it's a point, which is probably not too far away. 

 Q9.  You mentioned that an unallocated reserve policy of 10-20% and you  now are moving up on allocated reserves to 16% this quarter. Other banks commonly have unallocated reserve levels considerably higher  and it seems a little bit odd that you're this far into a credit  cycle and you're only now going into the upper half of that policy  range, how do you first ramp (Phonetic) up those issues? (Judah S.  Kraushaar - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  Our reading of the SEC policy is that you should not have an unallocated reserve that is significantly higher than that. With regard to where we are in the credit cycle, we don't really look at  it as where we are in the credit cycle. Our normal policy is that provision equals charge-off. We also run through this specific allocation methodology. If that policy leads us to one where we have too high an unallocated, then we would bring provision down below charge-off. If the reverse happened, if it was too low unallocated  as was in danger of happening last year, then we would raise the  provision to offset it. So I think our policy is very consistent. I  think it is absolutely in accordance with what the SEC wants, and it  is a methodology that we've followed for the past several years  fairly religiously. 

 Q10.  If the consumer continues to improve, you're going to have more releases of consumer reserves, and to keep provision equal to charge-offs, it would seem like you could get fairly quickly to a  case where you'd go above 20% unallocated. Would you let that  happen? Would you change the unallocated policy? (Judah S. Kraushaar  - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  No, we wouldn't let that happen. 

 Q11.  I think that investment management fees as apart from transactional  fees in the investment management business were flat this quarter.  Can you reconcile that with a drop in managed assets? In the investment bank, the core overhead ratio, apart from severance, went from 57-61%. I think your goal was 60%. Can we see any improvement  in 2H from these levels if markets don't really recover or are we  just going to hang above the goal indefinitely here? (Judah S.  Kraushaar - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  Of course, it gets easier as revenue increases. If revenue continues  to fall or be short of that, then it gets more difficult and we'll  have to decide where we land up, in terms of primarily compensation  as it relates to that level. We are looking at it carefully, both  trying to balance long-term and short-term interest, but I think  we've had a good record of managing expenses down to the significant  revenue shortfall we've had so far, and it's something that we'll  continue to try to manage to those levels. The ability to do it will  be somewhat dependent on where the revenue levels fall out. 

 A.  The A-1 (Phonetic) numbers that Dina talked about were quarter-end to quarter-end, and most of the market reduction occurred in June,  and there is somewhat of a lag between revenues associated with  investor management and the actual investor management number. Of  the $40b, $21b is represented of money market assets, which are  generally lower yielding, and of that $21b, $14.5b came from  specifically one government client where the yield on those assets  was less than 4 basis points. We are seeing net growth in our retail  assets, which are tending to be higher-yield. So, we would expect  some impact from the market reduction to flow through our revenue  number in 3Q02, although partially offset by the improvement in the  mix of our assets from institution to retail. 

 Q12.  History seems to teach us that when there's a poor quarter in trading, it usually snaps back fairly quickly, usually in the very following quarter. Do you feel that this is a different situation? This is a little philosophical, on Aug. 14; I gather you signed your name again. What are your thoughts and actions? How are you thinking differently or not about that, and what are you hearing from some of your peers? (Robert Albertson - Sandler O'Neill & Partners) 

 A.  I don't have a great crystal ball on what 3Q02 is going to look like  here. We did have a weak quarter in terms of trading. If you look at  our 1H02 vis--vis the other players, I would argue we're right in line. Some of the data I have shows us down about 20%, 1H02 over  1H01, and that's just about where everybody else was on the trading  side. The difficulty with predicting a quick snapback is two fold.  One is just these markets, and then the summer, which is definitely  a seasonal pattern to some of these things. So that's the difficulty  with making a prediction here. 

 Q13.  But is volatility lacking sufficiently? Is that the biggest bugaboo,  or is it just across the board? (Robert Albertson - Sandler O'Neill  & Partners) 

 A.  Volatility is certainly back, but some trend around it is the problem. 

 A.  With regard to the philosophical question, I would view that we sign  our names to any financial statements that we've ever put out, and  actually signing one more document probably doesn't make a whole lot  of difference. 

 Q14.  Do you think there are going to be changes in general because of this? (Robert Albertson - Sandler O'Neill & Partners) 

 A.  If you'd look at the broader issue of corporate America, I think the  closer scrutiny that people pay to all the practices that have grown  up over the last several years, it seems likely to me that there will be some additional changes in those practices. Given the fact that we have something like 6,000 public corporations, there's  likely to be some number of them that make changes as they apply  more scrutiny to a process and as practices, which maybe have been  laxed in the past get changed. That doesn't imply a fundamental  overhaul in the vast majority of very large companies in America.  We'll have to see how it comes out, but certainly that has been the  result so far. 

 Q15.  Can you update us on your telecom exposure? Why did the commercial  loan book and credit-related exposures grow this quarter, because  most of the companies that I have reported have had a flat-to-down  experience. (Chip Dickson - Lehman Brothers, Inc.) 

 A.  On the commercial exposure numbers, our actual commercial loans were  up slightly due to a large part to a couple of large over quarter-end client transactions, which actually now in the 3Q are no longer among us. We did see a rather dramatic upswing in our mark-to-market arena due to the movement in the dollar against other currencies as a general matter stepping down into our telecom exposure, we reported to you all a year ago and have subsequently published our credit-related assets as it relates to our telecom portfolio. We are down 15% in total credit-related assets on telecom since a year ago, basically pretty flat to the 1Q02 and we're continuing to manage that number as tightly as you would expect we would be. As part of our overall mix, it continues to be in the area that is giving the industry the most edge (Phonetic). (Suzanne Hammett) 

 Q16.  Could you tell us how the shared national credit exam went for J. P.  Morgan Chase? The shared national credit exam, how did it go for you? (Chip Dickson - Lehman Brothers, Inc.) 

 A.  We do not have our final numbers yet, but the preliminary indications are that actually we came out quite well, and we are particularly pleased with that preliminary performance against how  we felt we did last year, which wasn't poor, but we could improve  upon that performance. So we feel pretty good about what the outcome  will be of shared national credit, which should be basically an Aug.  event for us. 

 Q17.  About the outlook for the 2H, I guess so far that you guys have posted about a $1.15 and took consensus you'd have to hit $1.56 in  the 2H. Do you think that's reasonable, given where consensus is  today? (Andrew Collins - U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray Inc.) 

 A.  As you know, we don't comment on specific bottom-line EPS numbers, and we allow you to do your own work. 

 Q18.  Trading was kind of weak in June. I was wondering, so far how it's  going in July? If you could touch on the hedging gains, given the steepness in the yield curve, didn't you see a lot of mortgage servicing losses that might not be there going forward if the  hedging gains go away? (Andrew Collins - U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray  Inc.) 

 A.  Well, with regard to the former, we don't comment on it between quarters, in terms of what the outcome is because it changes so much from day-to-day. With regard to the latter, it of course is possible that if interest rates or mortgage rates don't change, that we will not see the servicing write-downs that we saw in the 2Q02. What happened in the 2Q02 was we had significant servicing write-downs,  but the assets that we had to hedge with those write-downs actually  more than offset that. So, what would happen in the 3Q02 is  anybody's guess. I think we have very good systems for managing that  risk. I think managing mortgage servicing risk is one of the most  complex things that any company can do and it is something that we  spend a great deal of time on, because it has importance to our  business. But I think it would be one of those areas where it would  be very difficult to predict what the outcome would be from  month-to-month. 

 Q19.  In the trading issue, you won't say one way or another about the Brazilian situation? (Andrew Collins - U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray Inc.) 

 A.  I'll say that we've reduced (Phonetic) our exposure, and I'll say that we continue to mark things to market. We're not necessarily always longing in our trading exposures. So, it's a question of getting it right and we'll have to see how it turns out. 

 Q20.  I'm trying to figure out the relationship between the bank's capital  and its trading activities. I make the assumption that the risk in  the derivatives portfolio is roughly equal to the company's common equity at the present time. I then make the further assumption that there is a constraint on your ability to expand your trading activities if you're in that situation. Could you clarify whether  that has any relevance or not? (Richard (Indiscernible) - Hoffer  Internet) 

 A.  Not only that's the way we would look at it. We've got two risks. One is our credit risk, in the derivative portfolio is a receivable  of about $70b.  When your net cash collateral is against that, it's between $45b and $50b. We look at that just like commercial loan exposures a $100b, consumer loan exposure is another $125b. We would look at the grade, the rating of the counter-party and we would  assign capital based on that rating. Actually, in our derivatives  portfolio 85% of the counter-parties are investment grade. Then the  second risk we've got is market risk, which generally, even in the  derivatives look (Phonetic), is smaller than the credit risk. So I  would say, now there is only one component of what we hold capital  for and on balance, I would say that if you look at derivative  activities or trading activities in general, it's certainly not the  largest component for which we hold capital. I don't feel  constrained with regard to the expansion of that activity. Our  capital ratios are very strong. 

 Q21.  At the moment, you don't feel that there is any link between the amount of capital in the institution and the amount of trading activity? (Richard (Indiscernible) - Hoffer Internet) 

 A.  What you said was that all our capital was devoted to it or we were  constrained by it, and I don't feel that way. 

 Q22.  In terms of research in general surety bonds either get paid right  away or they never get paid, and in fact, if they don't get paid even provision (Phonetic) of a lawsuit, how does that affect your reserves as a percent of loan? How does that affect your capital opportunities? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  The way we're accounting for the surety bonds is that they're held in other assets. FAS 5 (Phonetic) is very specific on this  situation. If you have a loss contingency or a contingent event that  might cause you to have a loss, if it's more probable than not that  it will happen, then you have to record the loss. If it is not more  probable than not, then you don't record the loss. In our case, our  opinion is that it is not probable that we will have a loss. We  believe that we will win the lawsuit and that the counter-parties  are creditworthy and will pay when they're ordered to do so by the  court. If we don't win, then we would have to write it down to the  value it on unsecured claim against Enron. It's not exactly an  all-or-nothing situation because the facts of some of the sureties  are slightly different than others, and we're dealing with 11  different insurance companies. In any event, when something occurs  that makes it change, either we get the money or there's a different  probability that we will get the money, then we would have an  accounting event that would happen at that time. There's no reserve.  It's not in-loan loss reserves. It was originally a trading asset.  We moved it to other assets. 

 Q23.  How much insurance do you have for potential lawsuits or criminal  fines or anything else you would dream up? Do you have insurance for  that, and how much? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  Well, we have lots of insurance, but sometimes the insurance companies don't pay. I don't know they were necessarily lying on  that insurance. I think we believe that we don't have liability in  these cases and we'll have to see how it works out. 

 Q24.  How much in reserves do you have for Argentina and Brazil, and how  does that compare to your cross-border exposure? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  In Argentina, our net exposure is about $200m and I think our gross  exposure would probably be around $500m, if you take effectively credit reserves that we have both in the trading book and in the  loan book. In Brazil, the reserves would be much smaller than that  as a percentage. The loan book we have are predominated by commodity producers who get their money in dollars and who wouldn't be  affected unless there was some severe currency controls. The  counter-parties that we have in the trading book are carried at  their current market spreads. So I think it's something, again, that  we've been clearly ahead of in terms of evaluating them at current  market. That's not to say we don't have exposure, if there is a much  more adverse situation than we presently have, but we are clearly  mark-to-market with regard to both trading book and reserves that  are sufficient to deal with the current outlook on the loan  portfolio. 

 Q25.  You've reduced your exposure in Brazil at a lot faster pace than some of your peers. How are you evaluating the  Brazilian situation? 

 A.  We're viewing it as a risky place right now and one in which we think it's appropriate to reduce our exposure. 

 Q26.  On the investment bank, if you look at the compensation expense, the  absolute number is down substantially from earlier last year, but the last three quarters, it's basically been pretty flat as an absolute number, despite rather volatile revenue. So, the first  issue is, does that say about bonus accruals during that period, and  what's your policy about that? It's flat at a rather low number in  the sense of mid 30s compensation expense ratio, how many downside  flexibility do you have in that number? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  One thing that's affected it in the last couple of quarters is the inclusion of severance costs in compensation, which we didn't have  in the 4Q01. We were charging it in a different way. We had some in  the 1Q and we had more in the 2Q. So, that has had some effect on  it. With regard to whether we can move down or whether we're  constrained because it's already at a very low level, there are some  structural reasons why ours is lower than some of our peers  including the inclusion of a loan portfolio, which has a lower  expense to revenue ratio. I think the size of our business enables  us to be more efficient. I do think, obviously there is some point,  which as revenues decline, gets more and more difficult to keep that  ratio in line. I don't know that we're at that point yet, but if we  get to much further declines in revenue, then there would be  something that would put pressure on that number. 

 Q27.  As you know, the Brazil (Phonetic) committee put out a press release  last week with some substantial changes in their proposals. Even  though they haven't publicly released the guidance for the quantitative impact study yet, they've been discussing it with the banks in some detail over the last few weeks. Are you in a position  at this point to talk at all about the effects of this on J. P.  Morgan Chase? 

 A.  It's pretty much of a changing landscape. From what we've seen, our  best guess is that it would probably result in lower required capital ratios for us. We are operating at capital ratios that are well above our regulatory required capital ratios today. I don't  know whether it would have a significant effect on what we carry,  because what we carry and what we think is appropriate to the risk  that we have today, without regard to regulatory minimums. But, I  think that from the little work we've done in a rapidly changing  landscape and some of it is hard to do because it calls for  significant technological investment to get the data that's  necessary to do it. Our general supposition would be that regulatory  minimums certainly are not going to go up, and may go down relative  to our adoption of the Brazil (Phonetic) conventions.

 Q1  2002 J.P.  Morgan  Chase & Co Earnings Conference Call - Final
