   LP
 CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS 

 . Dina Dublon, CFO   . (Indiscernible) 

   TD
 OVERVIEW 

 Operating earnings excluding JPMP, EPS for 1Q02 was $0.69, down $0.05 from 1Q01. Consolidated operating earnings for 1Q02 were $1.15b. Q&A focus: Business segments. 

 FINANCIAL DATA 

 A. Key Data From Call   1. Consolidated operating earnings for 1Q02 were $1.15b   2. Loan loss reserves were up $480m   3. Reserves are up by $1.3b from 1Q01   4. Non-performing assets are up almost $400m   5. 1Q02 operating expenses were $230m 

 PRESENTATION SUMMARY 

 A. 1Q02 Results Analysis - Dina Dublon   1. Operating earnings for 2001 have been restated by adding back      goodwill amortization to present 2001 results on a basis      comparable to 1Q02, which included the adoption of SFAS 142.   2. Results exceeded by a few cents, much better than weak 4Q. The      revenue environment remains slow and compared to the 1Q01,      results are down; therefore focus on expense management.     1. Credit costs decline from high 4Q as loan loss provision        equaled loan losted this quarter. 

 B. Business Segments - Dina Dublon   1. Retail lead the way with a record quarter.   2. Investment managment and private banking had the benefit of      lower expenses and a very large improvement in the pretax      margin.   3. The investment bank delivered ROE of 16% in a difficult      operating environment.   4. J.P. Morgan's partners (JPMP) recorded another loss driven by      the decline in the market price of Triton PCS.   5. Maintaining strong liquidity and capital and there is a premium      for both. 

 C. Earnings Per Share - Dina Dublon   1. Operating earnings excluding JPMP, EPS for 1Q02 was $0.69, down      $0.05 from 1Q01.   2. Consolidated operating EPS was contributed by JPMP with $0.12,      down from $0.17 4Q01.   3. Non-operating charges were $0.09. 

 D. Operating Results - Dina Dublon   1. Consolidated operating earnings for 1Q02 were $1.15b.   2. ROE for 1Q02 was 11% better than the prior three quarters but      still weak.   3. Relating to the 1Q01, revenues were down 8%, 5% of that decline      is from the loss from JPMP vs. a gain in the 1Q01.   4. Expenses were down by 8% as well.   5. JPMP realize gain for the quarter were negative $13m including about equal amount $170m each in cash realized gain and in write-offs from direct investments.   6. At $170m per quarter, write-offs are higher than what we can see      normal but do not see the systematic concentration issues that      drove the large loss last year.   7. Market-to-market losses was about $240m, about $200m of which      were driven by Triton PCS.   8. Excluding JPMP, the rest of the company earnings were about      $1.4b for 1Q02 compared to about $1.5b for 1Q01.   9. ROE for the rest of the company was 16% despite the state of the      capital market and where the company is in the credit cycle. 

 E. Operating Expenses - Dina Dublon   1. 4Q01 operating expenses was $4.8b, almost $800m lower than when      the company announced the merger. It was $3m lower annual      spending rate.   2. 1Q02 operating expenses were up and include $100m      non-merger-related Severance costs, the charge for Sumitomo and      the addition of Providian, a total of $230m.   3. Given softness in revenues, the company is already working to      reduce capacity. Costs of such actions will continue to flow      through operating expenses this year.   4. Each business is managing to a targeted overhead ratio inclusive      of costs to execute their program and all businesses are      managing to improve the ratio from last year.   5. As stated in Jan. on modest improvement in revenue, the company      was targeting flat expenses. Since then the company has closed      on the acquisition of Providian, which adds over $250m in expenses.   6. Without the revenues, the company will manage expenses to be      down from last year.   7. Expenses and revenues have been restated to reflect recent      accounting guidance effected in Jan. 

 F. Credit Costs - Dina Dublon   1. Commercial charge-offs are still at a very high level, 127 basis      points of loan. It is driven by pressure on the telecom sector,      an area of focus for the last year.   2. The credit card charge-off ratio is higher as expected. Losses      on the providian portfolio was included for two months.   3. Providian will contribute to a higher charge-off ratio on the combined portfolio.   4. In total, the provision for loan losses equaled charge-offs.   5. In 4Q01, loan loss provision exceeded charge-offs by $650m as      ratings in the commercial portfolio had deteriorated and losses      on consumer loans. 

 G. Reserves - Dina Dublon   1. Loan loss reserves were up $480m from Dec. primarily because of      the initial reserves setup for the Providian portfolio.   2. Reserves are up by $1.3b from 1Q01.   3. On the consumer side, the company should see lower reserve requirement.   4. In total, the company does not see the need to increase reserves      in 2002.   5. The ratio of commercial reserves to commercial loans is up to      1.8% in 1Q02 from 1.4% in 1Q01.   6. The ratio of total reserves to total loans is up to 2.3% in 1Q02      from 1.7% in 1Q01. 

 H. Non-performing Assets and Commercial Loans - Dina Dublon   1. Non-performing assets are up almost $400m primarily from one commercial loan in Europe.   2. Argentina was not an issue for the company this quarter.   3. Net of allocated reserves exposure is down to $360m with net      loans and commitment representing a little over $100m.   4. Commercial loans were down 10% from last year despite commitment. 

 I. Retail and Middle Market Results - Dina Dublon   1. Retail and middle market lead the way this quarter with record      earnings of $526m and ROE of 22%.   2. The Providian acquisition closed in early Feb. adding $150m to      revenues.   3. This coupled with the continuation of strong business volumes      lead to revenue growth of 18% over a year-ago quarter.   4. Card added new accounts of over 900,000, the sixth consecutive      quarter of such increases.   5. Mortgage had strong results driven by continued low interest      rates and with strong housing market.   6. Auto origination set a new record and deposit volumes up almost      14%.   7. The business experienced positive operating leverage from Six      Sigma productivity initiative.   8. The focus on end-to-end processing, doing it right the first      time, and explicit consideration of the voice of the client is      adding momentum to the retail business.   9. Credit cards increased from the 1Q due to higher outstanding and      higher loss ratio.   10. In total, provision for credit losses was $60m lower than consumer charge-offs in 1Q02 compared to $250m higher than charge-offs in the 4Q02. 

 J. Investment Managment and Private Banking - Dina Dublon   1. Investment management and private banking were up 30% from 4Q01      and 19% from 1Q01.   2. ROE was 8%, tangible ROE which eliminates the goodwill is higher      at 26%.   3. Revenue levels are down from 2001 but increased modestly from      4Q01.   4. Lower expenses drove the earnings growth and increase in pretax      margin to 22% despite higher credit costs in the last 6 months.   5. The retail fund business showed inflows from year-end with      particular strength on the international side, where inflows      were at five quarter high.   6. Investment bank earnings at $755m are down 27% from the 1Q and      more than double the low 4Q level. ROE was 16%.   7. Low market activity and high credit costs have continued to put      pressure on expense management.   8. Operating expenses in the quarter include the incremental costs      of settlement with Sumitomo, which belongs to this line of      business as well as Severance costs beyond the previously      planned merger and restructuring cost.   9. Despite the expense pressure created by the Severance,      Investment bank managed a very strong financial discipline to   10. An overhead ratio of 58%. This is lower than the prior target      of 60%.   11. Trading revenues were down 19% vs. a very strong 1Q01, the      second best ever, and were up 66% from a very low 4Q01, which      included the impact of Enron in Argentina.   12. Equities trading was down from 1Q01 but up from a very weak      4Q01. 13. Declines in advisory are in line with the peers, lost share in a very tight market.   14. The company was number three underwriter, for the first time,      of stocks and bonds globally. 

 K. Treasury and Security Services - Dina Dublon   1. Treasury and security services income is down about 15% from      both 4Q01 and 1Q01.   2. ROE was down to 19%.   3. Revenue decline was lead by investor services.   4. Institutional trust revenues were up from both 4Q01 and 1Q01.   5. Treasury services revenues were up from 1Q01 driven by higher      deposit volume.   6. Expenses were up 3% YoY and 4% from 4Q01. 

 L. Liquidity and Capital Management - Dina Dublon   1. Raised $8b in additional liquidity in 1Q02 and extended average      maturity of commercial paper and long-term debt.   2. Managing Tier 1 ratio that is higher that the target.   3. Resume repurchases when free capital generation accelerates. 

 M. In Summary - (Indiscernible)   1. The progress of the company since the merger has been obscure      due to the following four reasons: 1. The credit cycle becoming a much more negative affect on earnings causing the company to bear the results.     2. Reversal of the private equity valuation, which has caused        considerable reduction in what was previously earnings and in        need to write down some investments.     3. Weakness in all capital market activities, which the company        has not been immuned from in terms of decline in M&A marketplace and follow up on impact of that in terms of financing.     4. The publicity associated with Enron, which was true initially        and continues to be true.   2. The first three of those things are cyclical and the last,      hopefully, is a one-time event even though it may have a long      tail in terms of publicity. 

 QUESTION AND ANSWER SUMMARY 

 Q1.  Could you elaborate on what you are seeing as the leading indicators  of product mix? Could you give more quantification of your outlook  for expenses this year? Could you elaborate on that?  Are you looking for a dollar decline? (Ron Mandell [phonetic], co. name indiscernible) 

 A.  On the consumer side, it is easier to have a vision as to credit. We  are seeing an improvement in the delinquency rates particularly at this point in the earlier maturity. This has been a witness in evidence through 1Q02.  When we look across the board at the  portfolio overall, just give you a couple of stats and I want to  really stress that we are not drawing a straight line through the  stats and saying this is what the year is going to be. If we look at  auto finance for instance, 90-day delinquencies were 21 basis points  in 4Q and 16 in 1Q. The charge-offs that we are seeing the days that  have entered the buckets six months ago, 30-day delinquencies in  card have fallen from 4.77 to 4.57 or 20 basis points. In home  finance, we had across the board, although I don't have the stats at  my fingertips here, we have across the board reduction in  delinquencies even in the manufactured housing business, which  tended to be a pretty coincident indicator with the economy and we  are seeing increased charge-offs in manufactured housing. 

 Q2.  Could you comment on the commercial side? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  On the commercial side, during 1Q that compared to 4Q, a stabilization if you will of the risk deterioration in the  commercial portfolio and then we have the watch list of those names  that are at the bottom of our portfolio in terms of risk profile.  That volume has not materially increased QoverQ. 

 A.  On the commercial side, our charge-offs will continue to be higher than what we consider to be normal but we think anticipated that and that is why we added new reserves last year. There may be some need  on the commercial side and my guess is this is more than offset by  the easing of pressure on the consumer side and that is why we think  it is unlikely at this time that we would need charge earnings  beyond current charge-offs in this year. On the expenses, on the  issues that are there, we do have businesses that are growing as in  consumer business, we have had a positive spread between revenue and  expense growth. Compared to 1Q01, you have 18% outline revenue  growth and 13% (Indiscernible) are both somewhat influenced by the  acquisition of the Providian credit card acquisition. There is going  to be some growth there. There is going to be shrinkage in the areas  where we do not have revenue growth. We still think expenses will be  somewhat lower in this year than it was last year. 

 Q3.  You had mentioned Six Sigma showing off a (Indiscernible) retail. Can you update us (Indiscernible) new quantification of its  potential? Could you give us an update of any changes with the state  of play of the rating agencies? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  With regard to Six Sigma, we have projects on our way. We think the  opportunity for expense savings is on the magnitude of $0.5b. We are  also starting new projects as we go through the year. We have clearly seen the impact of both in the consumer side. Our consumer  is ahead of the game there, they would say, (Indiscernible) several hundred million dollars of benefit (Indiscernible) pipeline. So, I think the numbers can be quite large and we are optimistic about that.We really don't have anything new mid February which is when Moodys (Indiscernible) as stable, which had increased dialogue as  you would expect with the rating agencies this past six months vs.  what we used to have a year and half ago. 

 Q4.  Could you be a little bit more specific on the severance charges you  expect to (Indiscernible) your operating expenses? If FASB proposed  changes on (Indiscernible) go through, how about (Indiscernible)  targeted tier 1 capital ratio? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  The fact is anything that is new beyond what we estimated would be (Indiscernible) related to the merger and relocation initiatives  that had already begun prior to last year. That will be charged to non-operating. Anything else that is new will be charged to  operating expenses. Net of all those actions will be a slight  reduction of expense, but it maybe that it could be higher in 2Q and  you will get the benefits in 3Q and 4Q, but I will be reluctant to  forecast these at magnitude level. With respect to the impact of the  changes in the rules regarding (Indiscernible) the prospective  changes in the rules are so largely varying from day to day, but it  is a little bit hard to check exactly what the impact will be. We  think we have been conservative in applying the rules this far. The  rules may change and require some consolidation and our view is it  will not have a material impact on our ratios. We will probably  adjust (Indiscernible) because we think we have already captured the  economic risk of those activities in our internal capital  evaluation. Therefore, if we need to adjust external ratios for some  changes in the ground rules, we would consider doing that.  I would  be hesitant to because of the significant changes in ground rules. 

 Q5.  Within investment banking, (Indiscernible). Can you give more detail  into the (Indiscernible) continuing in 2Q? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  Fixed income has basically (Indiscernible) in doing well. The business that is more tended upon derivative interest rates (Indiscernible) and treasuries is doing worse than last year but at 20%, you recall last year's 1Q was highlighted by (Indiscernible) cutting rates dramatically and (Indiscernible). In terms on this quarter, bond issuance continues to do well. The theme is not (Alan Greenspan cutting rates but it is a general theme that corporations are showing up their (Indiscernible) spending maturities, reducing commercial papers, other short-term borrowings is the general trend, so that business we had originally thought before, (Indiscernible). 

 Q6.  Could you comment on the derivatives activity of (Indiscernible) trading and investment banking and also what happened in the custody business this quarter (Indiscernible)? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  (Indiscernible) a very long presentation on (Indiscernible) activities and earnings from those activities and risk control in those activities. 

 A.  The investor services are very heavily tied to the equities business  globally. If you look at the equity business, whether it is trading  or underwriting revenue, you will find the average industry is down  about 40-50%, so it has got a partial market (Indiscernible) of 50%.  On cost of custody competitors, our business model is (Indiscernible) more market sensitive than most (Indiscernible)  cross border custody, and that is the most market sensitive part of  the business. Revenues are down 10% for 1Q. Compared to 4Q, 1Q is  flat. 

 Q7.  Could you talk about the decision? What was the thought process in  terms of the decision to flatten out the reserve buildings? You had a couple of quarters where it was surprising, I understand you point that we are seeing some stabilization in credit ratings and some improvement in the consumer, but given all the intensity of issues surrounding credit, why have your levels flattened out so quickly? I am curious about the Providian acquisition reserves that you have established there, it sounds like you have lot of flexibility on consumer reserve and possibly excess reserves. Does that acquisition give particular flexibility to go down? (Jay Vleeschhouwer  (Phonetic) - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  Our reserving policy is a fairly quantitative exercise. We go through on commercial loans and evaluate (Indiscernible) loss on problem credit and general list of loss on the rest of our portfolio based on historical loss rates for certain buckets. We do the same thing on a consumer side based on the average length of life of each type of credit and the expected loss rate for those credits both, a little bit historical but mostly expected loss rate over the next  year or so for those credits. When that has the impact, when things  are deteriorating it causes you to front-end the impact of those  charges. Front-end in terms of preserving in anticipation of future  losses. That combined with our policy, which is,to take losses  aggressively . So, I think it is not possible (Phonetic), for  example, back in Argentina, we did absorb all of our losses in 4Q01  and reserve part of the building of reserves last quarter was  specifically for Argentina. On Enron that we charged down last  quarter to less than 20% of the phase of the North (Phonetic). I  think the reserve policy combined with an aggressive recognition of  loss policy is what makes it more painful as you go through the  early part of the difficult part of the credit cycle. But, it gets  you to the peak faster and when (Indiscernible) actually reserves  will come down at that point for sure. I think what has changed for  us is the lessening of likelihood that consumer houses are going to  continue to build throughout the year. I would say as in 4Q01, we  might get with a more negative outlook for the economy and looking at delinquencies as that might continue to build throughout the  year. Now, our (Indiscernible) probably getting close to a  (Indiscernible) and consumer loss rate and therefore the need to add  to reserves or maybe even the expectation that we had last year when  we established the reserves that the now expected loss rate may be a  little bit lower than what those expectations were. So, I think what  has changed is the real economy has changed, our outlook and our  experience has changed and therefore it causes a more abrupt change  in our (Indiscernible) and that's the product of the new world that  we live in, which causes us to want to upfront, the top. With  regards to Providian, when we acquired the Providian assets,  eventhough they are in a securitized trust, the rules are that all  has to be consolidated on the balance sheet until such time as those  credit cards are (Indiscernible). They are deemed to be securitized  receivable. At that time, they tend to flow out and that would take  about 18 months. So, that portfolio will run down on our book and  therefore the reserve for them will run down on our book. From an  accounting standpoint, that is offset by the fact that the goodwill that was created with the reserves is amortized over in 5 years. So, in effect we have got some accounting charges that relates to the accounting and we do have some relief from the fact that the  provision generally will be lowered in charges related to that  statistics part of the portfolio. 

 Q8.  On the reserves that you have in Providian, if you look at the reserves relative to expected loss today of that portfolio vs. the rest of the card portfolio, how does that relationship compare? (Jay Vleeschhouwer (Phonetic) - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  It would be higher because we would expect to have higher losses. 

 Q9.  Will the ratio itself be higher? (Jay Vleeschhouwer (Phonetic) - Merrill Lynch) 

 A.  The ratio itself will be higher. 

 Q10.  Last quarter it was said that expenses were going to be flat and now  it is pointed out that they will be down and that includes $150m association expenses with Providian as well as the severance. Can  you give us any update on how we should think about the severance  going forward vs. this quarter? (Henry HcVey - Morgan Stanley) 

 A.  Yes. We are looking at expenses to be lower including the cost of Providian, which was not $150m for the year. They are higher than that. They were $48m or $46m for the first two months. They will  have a higher levels (Indiscernible) as we go forward. But, I don't  think I indicated the level of expenses for Providian for the year.  Yet, it includes Providian and includes severance cost. It is right  to our revenue outlook, more cautious than the revenue outlook we  had in Jan. on the capital market side and on the investment bank  side. The context in which we are looking to have the expenses being  lower than last year. 

 Q11.  Can you give us any magnitude, you were talking about 5% or more?  (Henry HcVey - Morgan Stanley) 

 A.  I can't give you a magnitude because it all depends on the revenue environment. I think it's really an indication for you that we are responding to revenue pressures by managing expenses. So, the focus  on the overhead ratio will become (Indiscernible). 

 Q12.  Can you just mention briefly about share buybacks? Can you just walk  through your mindset on what would be the data point need to go back  into repurchase? (Henry HcVey - Morgan Stanley) 

 A.  I think we feel right now that it's time to be building our capital  ratios. We don't know fully what the impact of the consolidation  will be that will have some impact on capital ratios. We are not  quite at the end of this credit cycle. So, we feel it is prudent to  have strong capital ratio. The datapoint that would take to resume  share buyback would be stronger generation of internal earnings,  stronger earnings than what we have right now would be higher  capital ratios than right now. (Indiscernible) credit cycle. I think  all three of those things are going to happen and I don't know whether it would be at the end of this year or sometime next year. But, I think there are clearly going to happen and I think there  will be a point at which we have significant generation of capital.  We have been retarded (Indiscernible) about the semi (Phonetic)  non-operating charges, which are going down from last year's 2.5b  (Indiscernible) to this year 1.2b (Indiscernible). When we talked  about very low earnings, which we think have the potential to be  higher, we have had good control of the balance sheet. Our  commercial loans are down 10% from a year ago. They are down 3% from  year-end and despite of all the pressures that were in the  commercial paper market. So, I think we have had very tight control  of the balance sheet and that will continue and that will give us,  as these other factors come into play, significant free generation  of capital and will enable significant buyback at some point in time  or else there will be deployment of that capital into profitable  growth. 

 Q13.  On Fleming Asset Management division, did the contracts roll off at  the end of last year so that will help on the comp side? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  The contracts did roll off. So, you are seeing part of that on the Fleming side. 

 Q14.  You said that you have the highest international flows in five quarters. Can you just give us some colors of retail, institutional, and what do you see driving that? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  In terms of the retail asset that is seen and talked about internationally, it was the strongest, was essentially flat institutionally and there were mutual funds both in Europe and in Asia, with high yield in asset rolling in. 

 A.  Assets under the management at the end of 1Q was said wrongly in the  summary, it was said as 538, it should be 583, and that is down from  a level of 605 in 4Q. 

 A.  The highest margin assets are the European and a retail equity mutual fund and that is where we are beginning to see some more  funds (Phonetic). 

 A.  In the retail, 1Q over 4Q were up 16%. 

 Q15.  Looking at the level of the interest income and interest expense and  the yield of the spread, in light of the current economic environment, in terms of interest rates going forward, what are you looking forward in terms of the rate situation and what are you looking for in terms (Indiscernible) perhaps better improved mix margin on the interest? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  Our view is that the economy is improving and will continue to improve and that rates will begin to go up some time this Summer or Fall. We are not particularly exposed plus or minus to the impact of rising rates. So, I don't think it will have a negative effect on  us. I think the effect will be more positive because of the pickup  in economic activity and it has impact on (Indiscernible), on cost  equity evaluation, and on the M&A. The impact on net interest income  will be fairly neutral, but the impact on the business will be  positive. 

 Q16.  (`DUE TO DIFFICULTIES IN CALL AUDIO, THIS PORTION OF THE EVENT BRIEF  SUMMARY HAS BEEN EXCLUDED.`) Is that true? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  We might not be using that. 

 Q17.  Goodwill declined $278m or so in the quarter. Was there an impairment taken that didn't float (Phonetic) with the income statement or was there some unusual adjustment? (Indiscernible) 

 A.  I think there (Indiscernible) reclassification from goodwill to intangibles as we are looking at what need to be amortized going forward. 

 Q18.  Dollar amount delinquencies did rise pretty significantly in the credit card business sequentially. Was any of that related to (Indiscernible)? 

 A.  We didn't take some that are delinquent. So, with the $8b addition to the portfolio and the fact that it was (Indiscernible) on Feb. 1 and the data was on March 31. There would be some significant impact from delinquencies on the portfolio. I think most of that portfolio went up a little bit as 90-day delinquencies are up slightly, 30-day and 60-day delinquencies are down. 

 Q19.  In the past few years, you have spoken about the retail area that  things were going very rapidly (Indiscernible). What are the factors  that are causing this rapid growth in retail? 

 A.  I would definitely say good management. Across the board, we have very strong underlying businesses and Chase (Indiscernible) finance who were the #2 originator #3 servicer, generated $180b of mortgage product last year. That pace of activity has continued into 1Q. We have a great mortgage company. In the card business we talked last time about why we were interested in (Indiscernible). I think we  began by saying what we feel is that the new management team there  for the last two years has created a very solid operational platform  that we could build off of. We are beginning to see that they have  also created a marketing platform. This year, in 2002, we will plan  to do what we call 35,000 marketing tests. The degree of market  penetration is up from 500 market tests two years ago. As you look  at the products we are putting out and the branch and new market  structure we have in New York, we are just seeing great flows. We  are seeing the results of getting the kind of the top line growth  out of this franchise that affects this underlying strength. 

 Q20.  As the leader and loans indications (Phonetic) and introduction of  market flex, could you talk a little bit about what you are seeing in terms of pricing flexibility in the base of corporate demand to term out their credits? How much room do you think you might have to cut your loan portfolio even as your clients (Indiscernible) might  be even more interested in taking down bank debt as opposed to more  market sensitive credits? (Diane Grossman (Phonetic) - UBS Warburg) 

 A.  We are seeing an up tick in terms of the leverage finance area right  now but for the specific pricing standpoint. I don't have a specific  answer. 

 A.  I don't think the price of (Indiscernible) is strong as you think it  would be in this environment. I think we are still dealing with very  low margins. 

 Q21.  Do you see any ability to push that at the merger or willingness to  perhaps take more credit on balance sheet temporarily with a view towards being able to term it out as the market turns around? (Diane Grossman (Phonetic) - UBS Warburg) 

 A.  We haven't changed our standards about the need to syndicate 90% or  more of credits and that have been central to our philosophy in terms of diversifying credit exposure, and that remains our standards. 

 A.  The important pint here is that we continue to be very aggressive in  this marketplace. We have taken a very sharp look at our overall portfolio that the marketplace continued aggressive stand, both in terms of our willingness to commit capital and aggressiveness in pricing. Having said that, we are trying to be exceeding (Indiscernible). We see an environment out there particularly as we see companies take strategic moves and combining those strategic  moves and looking out what (Indiscernible) finance activity is. We  have used our balance sheet quite aggressively in helping find  through that period of time. In general, we are seeing exceedingly  competitive market. City Groups (Phonetic) in particular have been  quite aggressive and we have been responding to that. We have  maintained our leadership position and we have been improving.  Particularly (Indiscernible) sequentially has started to increase  over the last couple of months. 

 Q22.  Can you give us a sense of how we should project the corporate line  that had $150m loss this quarter and $257m in 4Q? How should we think about that going forward? (John Coffee (Phonetic) - City  Groups (Phonetic)) 

 A.  I think you should think about it as a small loss. There are at times when we had charges that don't get allocated but our instinct over time is to try to make that as small as possible and allocate everything else. Over time I would expect it to be something that would (Indiscernible). 

 Q23.  What kind of things might have shown up in that line item in this  quarter vs. 4Q? (John Coffee (Phonetic) - City Groups (Phonetic)) 

 A.  The reason why it came down from 4Q is that part of the unallocated  provision increased in 4Q went to the corporate sector. 

 Q24.  When you think small, you mean smaller than a $150m? (John Coffee  (Phonetic) - City Groups (Phonetic)) 

 A.  The problem is that there are about 50 things that going into it. Overtime what I would do is expect it to be a smaller. 

 Q25.  Fleet made some comments yesterday about their exposure to venture  capital business and the fact that they wanted to pre-limit their  exposure. On a defactor (Phonetic) basis, you have been lessening  your exposure but haven't really heard any philosophical discussion  of that business and its claim on capital. Can you address that?  Excluding the four special and not controllable factors that impacted the merger, where do you feel the Chase-Morgan merger has worked really well and where has it worked really poorly? (Nancy  Bush (Phonetic) - (Indiscernible)) 

 A.  We had a great private equity business, and one that has outperformed over a long period of time. On the other had we feel  that we had had too large a concentration (Indiscernible). The best  way to deal with that over time is to invest less going forward. We  are doing that by getting (Indiscernible) money and by lowering the  pace of investment. Right now, we are around 21% or 22%  (Indiscernible) capital in terms of that $8.5b balance of that  portfolio. Prior to the merger that number was as high as 38%. Our  target overtime will be to reduce that to around 15% and that will  happen because of a lower (Indiscernible) over a several year period  of time. I think it is a business that integrates well and thus  produce above average shareholder returns overtime. With respect to  the merger, what has worked well is the people integrations., trying  to get people from two large institutions has worked well and  relative to the expectation in these mergers, our retention has been  set. This difficult market environment has made it more problematic.  Over the long time of course, it is not bad to go through difficult  periods because it forces team work that cause people to work  together. Expenses are set and we calibrate that in a way that over  time it will produce much more earnings. It has been a challenge. 

 A.  We have merged about a year and a quarter ago. We overall have seen  share in a shrinking market but we have seen share in the first year  of merger.
